docs.lead_paragraph: In April, after a well-publicized wave of protests against the lewd language and fisticuffs on ''The Jerry Springer Show,'' its owner, Studios USA, announced that it would eliminate all physical violence from that daily television talkfest. A few weeks later -- reportedly pressed by Mr. Springer -- the syndicator altered that policy, saying it would ''responsibly edit'' each show to tone down the violence, while keeping the confrontational formula that makes the show so popular.
docs.abstract: Last April, after well-publicized wave of protests against lewd language and fisticuffs on The Jerry Springer Show, its owner, Studios USA, announced that it would eliminate all physical violence from talk show; few weeks later, reportedly pressed by Springer, syndicator altered policy and brawling or attempted brawling has resumed; show's ratings have risen in tandem with ribaldry; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Patrick J. Frawley Jr., a high school dropout who made millions of dollars in business, gave millions to conservative causes and candidates, then made it his business and his life's work to combat alcohol and drug addiction, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 75 and lived in Agoura, Calif. His family said he died during surgery for lung cancer.

headline.main: Patrick Frawley Jr., 75, Ex-Owner of Schick

docs.lead_paragraph: A giant pink ribbon was ceremonially cut and Long Island breast cancer activists hugged and applauded. A 240-year-old landmark, Hewlett House, was being rededicated as the nation's first comprehensive community education and resource center for breast cancer patients and their families. ''With the extraordinary commitment of our community of supporters in business and politics, we have raised money and awareness, fighting for a cure and looking for the causes of breast cancer,'' Geri Barish of Baldwin, executive director of the Hewlett House project, said at the Oct. 27 ceremony.

headline.main: Transformed by Passion and Politics, Breast Cancer Movement Gains Power

docs.abstract: Article on rising power of breast cancer movement in US; focuses on recent rededication of landmark Hewlett House on Long Island as US's first comprehensive community education and resource center for patients and families; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: David Frum (''Hangman, Spare That Ideology,'' Op-Ed, Nov. 6) urges Republicans to stick to their socially conservative agenda. But Mr. Frum's worry that liberals will ''dangerously expand the powers of the state and drastically infringe on the rights of parents to determine how their children will be educated'' does not take into consideration that it is conservatives who try to force religious worship into public schools.

headline.main: Midterm Elections: A Vote for Moderation?; Social Conservatism?

docs.lead_paragraph: YOU know who I want to meet?'' the good doctor asks. ''The sick, twisted little bean counter who came up with the health maintenance organization.'' As a prickly but secretly noble physician who spouts outrageous truths, Ted Danson's John Becker is no more believable than the saintly Marcus Welby was. But here, in a promotional spot for the new CBS sitcom ''Becker,'' he sounds oddly realistic, echoing opinions heard more and more often, on and off television. Under the heading ''Becker on H.M.O.'s,'' the harangue continues: ''You go in with a headache; they do a credit scan before a CAT scan. Need surgery? They biopsy your wallet. H.M.O.'s, you know what H.M.O.'s stand for? Have money or die.'' More astute than the labored series itself, the promo sounds a theme that medical dramas have also leaped on this season. ''Chicago Hope,'' ''E.R.'' and the new ''L.A. Doctors'' have all included more than one major story pointedly attacking H.M.O.'s. The shows reflect the widespread image of H.M.O.'s as faceless, heartless monoliths that would rather save a penny than save a life. On ''Chicago Hope,'' Dr. Aaron Shutt (Adam Arkin) runs into an H.M.O. representative who has been reviewing the doctor's prescription for an expensive drug.

headline.main: On the Doctor Shows, Public Health Enemy No. 1

docs.abstract: Caryn James article on issue of health maintenance organizations that has crept into most television sitcoms and dramas about doctors and hospitals; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DR. KEVIN MALONEY is an anachronism. In an age when doctors seem increasingly impersonal and difficult to reach even on the telephone, 47-year-old Dr. Maloney is just this side of startling. He loves to talk -- in fact, he talks a lot; he is friendly and casual; he gives his home phone number to patients. He even concedes to a couple of personal weaknesses; he is hooked on cigarettes (''I tell people never get started because it is really a terrible addiction,'' he said) and in a day consumes five or six extra-large Coffee Coolattas from the Dunkin' Donuts near his office here. Dr. Maloney is also generous with his time and expertise. In his private family practice, if someone cannot pay the going rate, that person pays what he can, when he can.

headline.main: The View From/Mamaroneck; A Doctor Whose Giving Doesn't End at the Office

docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Kevin Maloney of Mamaroneck, NY, who, in his spare time, runs St Rita's Free Medical Clinic at Holy Trinity Church; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as city and state officials were clinching a deal last week to keep one financial market in Manhattan, the New York Stock Exchange increased the pressure for its own generous deal by talking to developers about building a new trading floor in Jersey City. The routine threat to cross the Hudson drew the routine reaction: officials in New York put a $600 million incentive package on the bargaining table, a sum that would cover more than half the cost of building and outfitting a new headquarters for the New York Stock Exchange directly across from its historic home on Wall Street, according to negotiators on both sides of the talks.

headline.main: Wall Street Plays Relocation Card, and City Pays

docs.abstract: New York City officials, in effort to keep New York Stock Exchange from relocating to Jersey City, NJ, offer $600 million incentive package (M)
